items.summary:
Le indagini forensi digitali richiedono professionisti specializzati che sappiano gestire strumenti complessi, rispettare procedure legali e ricostruire sequenze di eventi. La validità delle prove dipende dall'integrità della catena di custodia e dal rispetto delle normative vigenti
L'articolo <a href="https://www.agendadigitale.eu/documenti/giustizia-digitale/dati-legge-e-indagini-perche-serve-lesperto-forense-digitale/">Dati, legge e indagini: perché serve l’esperto forense digitale<
items.author: Pier Luca Toselli

items.title: AI firm claims it stopped Chinese state-sponsored cyber-attack campaign
items.summary: Anthropic says financial firms and government agencies were attacked ‘largely without human intervention’A leading artificial intelligence company claims to have stopped a China-backed “cyber espionage” campaign that was able to infiltrate financial firms and government agencies with almost no human oversight.The US-based Anthropic said its coding tool, Claude Code, was “manipulated” by a Chinese state-sponsored group to attack 30 entities around the world in September, achievin
items.author: Aisha Down

items.title: Father of teen whose death was linked to social media has ‘lost faith’ in Ofcom
items.summary: Ian Russell says watchdog lacks ‘urgency’ and is not willing to use its powers ‘to the extent required’ The father of Molly Russell, a British teenager who killed herself after viewing harmful online content, has called for a change in leadership at the UK’s communications watchdog after losing faith in its ability to make the internet safer for children.
items.author: Dan Milmo Global technology editor

items.title: Personal details of Tate galleries job applicants leaked online
items.summary: Sensitive information relates to more than 100 individuals and their refereesPersonal details submitted by applicants for a job at Tate art galleries have been leaked online, exposing their addresses, salaries and the phone numbers of their referees, the Guardian has learned.The records, running to hundreds of pages, appeared on a website unrelated to the government-sponsored organisation, which operates the Tate Modern and Tate Britain galleries in London, Tate St Ives in Cornw

items.title: The Download: how AI really works, and phasing out animal testing
items.summary: This is today’s edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. OpenAI’s new LLM exposes the secrets of how AI really works The news: ChatGPT maker OpenAI has built an experimental large language model that is far easier to understand than typical models. Why…

items.title: These technologies could help put a stop to animal testing
items.summary: Earlier this week, the UK’s science minister announced an ambitious plan: to phase out animal testing. Testing potential skin irritants on animals will be stopped by the end of next year, according to a strategy released on Tuesday. By 2027, researchers are “expected to end” tests of the strength of Botox on mice. And drug tests…

items.title: Five U.S. Citizens Plead Guilty to Helping North Korean IT Workers Infiltrate 136 Companies
items.summary:
The U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ) on Friday announced that five individuals have pleaded guilty to assisting North Korea's illicit revenue generation schemes by enabling information technology (IT) worker fraud in violation of international sanctions.
The five individuals are listed below -

Audricus Phagnasay, 24
Jason Salazar, 30
Alexander Paul Travis, 34
Oleksandr Didenko, 28, and
Erick

items.title: North Korean Hackers Turn JSON Services into Covert Malware Delivery Channels
items.summary:
The North Korean threat actors behind the Contagious Interview campaign have once again tweaked their tactics by using JSON storage services to stage malicious payloads.
"The threat actors have recently resorted to utilizing JSON storage services like JSON Keeper, JSONsilo, and npoint.io to host and deliver malware from trojanized code projects, with the lure," NVISO researchers Bart Parys, Stef
items.author: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

items.title: Researchers Find Serious AI Bugs Exposing Meta, Nvidia, and Microsoft Inference Frameworks
items.summary:
Cybersecurity researchers have uncovered critical remote code execution vulnerabilities impacting major artificial intelligence (AI) inference engines, including those from Meta, Nvidia, Microsoft, and open-source PyTorch projects such as vLLM and SGLang.
"These vulnerabilities all traced back to the same root cause: the overlooked unsafe use of ZeroMQ (ZMQ) and Python's pickle deserialization,"
